title: black sabbath
content:
hi! someone can identify this font? thanx in advance

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Immagine1_4922.jpg)
author: rockberto

comments.content: Reminds me of [De Vinne](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/De+vinne) and [Bernase Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/e-daylight.jp/design/fonts/type/b/bernase-roman.html) but /R looks off for both of them...
Good call, Bob! Didn't know this rough interpretation of De Vinne/Bernase Roman by Harold Lohner. To remember! Thanks.

That's it Bob! The rubber stamps Harold Lohner used for Artistamp Medium  
 [http://www.identifont.com/similar?KHJ](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.identifont.com/similar?KHJ "http://www.identifont.com/similar?KHJ")  
look like they were based on a condensed version of the circa 1900 De Vinne design, with the R and Q edited to be less floppy.  
For a digital variation of condensed De Vinne with smooth letters see Hawthorne:  
 [http://www.identifont.com/similar?6EF](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.identifont.com/similar?6EF "http://www.identifont.com/similar?6EF")  
A regular width version of DeVinne was recently digitized by Jeff Levine as Publication: [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/publication/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/publication/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/publication/")  
Also De Vinne from wooden type fonts:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/de-vinne/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/de-vinne/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/de-vinne/")  
For a rubber stamp treatment of the wider width of De Vinne see Harold Lohner's Hand Stamped JNL:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/hand-stamped/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/hand-stamped/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/hand-stamped/")  
The De Vinne typeface has been discussed many times before at typophile, most recently at:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/104584](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/typophile.com/node/104584 "http://typophile.com/node/104584")  
Don

Just a note that [De Vinne](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/http:/fontsinuse.com/typefaces/7888/de-vinne) had an alternate ‘R’ without a descending leg. Here are both forms in the [1923 ATF catalog](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323/https:/archive.org/stream/1923AmericanTypeFoundersSpecimenBookCatalogue/1923ATFSpecimenBook#page/n351/mode/2up):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725005323im_/http:/typophile.com/files/de%20vinne%20condensed%20no_6465.2.png)

Thanks Stephen, for the comment on the DeVinne alternate straight R leg in ATF 1923. I own a copy of the book and on checking, I found that you are indeed correct. Never noticed before. As Stan says in South Park, I learned something today.  
Don
